intro.description: SQL patterns are different to Regular patterns. For example, if you search strings starting with 'S', the regular pattern is 'S%', as opposed to 'S.*'. SQL patterns are more easily supported by databases: they appear in the « LIKE » clauses of SQL statements. Queries with SQL patterns tend to be faster than queries with regular expressions although they are usually far less powerful. Please refer to your Database Management System documentation for more details.

item.title: Set SQL pattern information and content
item.description:
To open the New SQL Pattern wizard, expand the Libraries node and the Patterns folder on the DQ Repository Tree view. Right click SQL and then click New SQL Pattern on the context menu. The wizard prompts you to provide the SQL pattern metadata (name, purpose, description and expression...). Upon completion, an editor opens in which you can modify or add to the pattern metadata or definitions.
Click Pattern Definition to expand the editor. In this section of the editor, you can create database specific pattern definitions. Select the database type from the list and enter the expression in the corresponding field.
